abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Structural
            Adjustment Credit for Cape Verde were as follows: the
            outcome was highly satisfactory, the sustainability was
            likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            highly satisfactory. The lessons learned show that the
            programs addressing crisis situations work when there are
            dynamic teams in the Government and the Bank that are able
            to bring together the necessary expertise and to take
            necessary decisions and actions to bring about quickly the
            needed support in the case of the bank and the policy
            changes in the case of the Government. The Structural
            Adjustment Credit (SAC) was designed and approved in four
            months, ahead of the IMF program, an approach which was
            supported by the IMF. Identification of key measures and
            simplicity are critical to the success of reform programs in
            general, but particularly of those geared to addressing
            severe short-term imbalances. The program targeted a few key
            reforms which were central to the reform program. This
            reduced the burden on Government and ensured that it focused
            on key issues. Experience with the Cape Verde program
            confirms the importance of Government commitment and buy in
            of all stakeholders in bringing about needed changes. Close
            coordination within the Bank increases the effectiveness of
            Bank assistance and reduces costs. During preparation and
            supervision of the SAC, Bank teams in different units worked
            closely together and with the IMF and other donors. There is
            a need to provide appropriate Technical Assistance resources
            to support the implementation of the adjustment measures.
            The availability of SAC PPF reflows, (amounts left from the
            original allocation that were preserved in a project
            account), which the Government agreed to utilize for studies
            and capacity building and other sources of financing allowed
            for essential technical work on key structural and budget
            measures mentioned in the Letter of Development Policy
            (LDP), including petroleum sector reform, the Public
            Expenditure Review (PER), the assessment of the pension
            system, and the analysis carried out on investment
            incentives by Foreign Investment Advisory Service (FIAS).
